{{Infobox comedian | name = Hari Kondabolu | image = Hari Kondabolu.png | imagesize = | caption = Hari Kondabolu during an interview | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|10|21}} | birth_place = [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[film]], [[podcast]]s | nationality = [[United States|American]] | active = 2000s–present | genre = {{hlist|[[Observational comedy]]|[[political satire]]}} | subject = {{hlist|[[Politics of the United States|American politics]]|[[Culture of the United States|American culture]]|[[Culture of India|Indian culture]]|[[popular culture|pop culture]]||[[civil rights]]|[[Racism in the United States|racism]]}} | spouse = | signature = | website = {{url|http://harikondabolu.com}} | footnotes = | alma_mater = {{unbulleted list|[[Bowdoin College]]|[[Wesleyan University]]|[[London School of Economics]]}} | relatives = [[Ashok Kondabolu]] (brother) }} '''Hari Karthikeya Kondabolu'''{{cite news|url=https://www.bowdoin.edu/magazine/archives/2011/pdf/Bowdoin-Vol82_No.2.pdf|title=Stand Up With a Social Conscience|last=Beem|first=Edgar Allen|work=Bowdoin|publisher= [[Bowdoin College]]|location=Maine|date=Summer 2011|volume=82|issue=2|page=39|access-date=2016-08-05|via=}} ({{lang-te|హరి కొండబోలు}}; born 1982)Beem, p. 38 is an [[United States|American]] [[stand-up comedy|stand-up comic]], actor, filmmaker, and podcast host. He is best known for his comedy on subjects such as race, identity, inequality, and the LGBT community. He has appeared on television on many occasions, and was a writer for ''[[Totally Biased with W. Kamau Bell]]''. ==Early life and family== Kondabolu was born in the [[Flushing, Queens|Flushing]] neighborhood of the New York City borough of [[Queens]] in 1982, to Ravi and Uma Kondabolu, who had immigrated from [[Tenali]] in [[Andhra Pradesh|Andhra Pradesh, India]].{{Cite web|url=http://bklynr.com/hari-kondabolu-walks-into-a-bar/|title=Bklynr {{!}} Hari Kondabolu Walks Into a Bar|website=bklynr.com|access-date=2016-04-22}}{{Cite web|url=http://rollingstoneindia.com/the-small-town-south-indian-boys-of-new-york/|title=The Small Town South Indian Boys Of New York|last=Sharma|first=Neha|date=2012-04-20|website=Rolling Stone India|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-08}} Soon after Ravi had immigrated to the United States in 1978,{{Cite news|url=|title=Metro People in Profile: Ravi Kumar Kondabolu, Chief Technologist, New York Flushing Hospital|last=Bertrand|first=Donald|date=1998-10-05|work=|newspaper=New York Daily News|page=4|quote=Then came word in 1992 that the Indian government planned to use the Wyra acreage for other purposes. "My brother and I rushed back to India and offered our own money to start the college," he said. In 1994, Kondabolu Venkaiaah Choudary Memorial began in rented quarters with only 28 students.... Ravi, who lives in Jamaica Estates, said he works long hours as chief technologist in the cardiology department of New York Flushing Hospital in an effort to send at least $15,000 annually back to India to support the college.|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} while in a small town in Louisiana, he says he was approached by a person who asked, "Excuse me, sir, are you Chinese?"{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/02/08/273768850/people-language-and-controversy-in-the-headlines|title=People, Language And Controversy In The Headlines|last=|first=|date=2014-02-08|website=NPR.org|series=All Things Considered|publisher=National Public Radio|access-date=2016-08-08}} Both parents were physicians in India, and became the heads of New York area medical labs; Ravi is chief technologist at a cardiology lab and Uma never practiced as a physician in the US.{{Cite news|url=|title='The real adventurous people are my parents'|last=Pais|first=Arthur J.|date=2013-09-06|work=|newspaper=India Abroad|pages=M5,M10|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} Ravi has worked at the Flushing Hospital Medical Center since 1981.{{Cite news|url=|title=Indian-American Establishes College Back Home|last=Swamy|first=Prakash M.|date=1998-07-03|work=|newspaper=News India - Times|page=4|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} Ravi's father, Venkaiah Choudhury, had been an Indian freedom fighter, a member of the Communist movement and a member of the Andhra Pradesh state assembly. In 1994, after years of work, Ravi was able to fulfill his dream by opening a college in Wyra in the [[Khammam district]] in India.{{Cite news|url=|title='We never forgot where we came from'|last=Pais|first=Arthur J.|date=2013-09-06|work=|newspaper=India Abroad|pages=M2,M4|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Ravi Kondabolu, chief technician of Cardiology Dept. at Flushing Hospital Medical Center|last=Dutt|first=Ela|date=1998-09-25|work=India in New York|page=18|quote=In 1991, when politicians threatened to take over 31 of the 15 acres of land [Ravi Kondabolu]'s father had bought in 1963 to built a college in Wyra township, Khammam district in Andhra Pradesh, friends informed Ravi who lived in the United States. Within months the Kondabolu Venkaiah Chaudhary Memorial College (KVCM) opened its doors to 29 students more than 30 years after his father envisioned it.|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} Half the seats at the memorial college (now a polytechnic) are reserved for women. Kondabolu credits his mother with having and expressing unusually progressive views on gay rights during his childhood, and says she is both "the reason I'm funny" and "the funniest person I know".{{cite AV media |date=2016-07-22 |title=Mainstream American Comic |medium=Comedy album |language=English |url=https://harikondabolu.bandcamp.com/album/mainstream-american-comic |section=My Mom (Accent Not Included) |publisher=Kill Rock Stars}} Kondabolu is the older brother of [[Ashok Kondabolu|Ashok]], who is a former member of the group [[Das Racist]].{{cite web|url=http://rollingstoneindia.com/the-small-town-south-indian-boys-of-new-york/|title=The Small Town South Indian Boys Of New York|author=Neha Sharma |date=April 20, 2012|publisher=Rolling Stone India|accessdate=2012-10-30}} As Indian-Americans of [[Telugu people|Telugu origin]] they are unusual: "Growing up I’d tell people, even other Indians, that I was Telugu and they would have no idea what that meant."{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanbazaaronline.com/2014/03/04/hari-kondabolu-growing-up-id-tell-people-even-other-indians-that-i-was-telugu-and-they-would-have-no-idea-what-that-meant/|title=Growing up I’d tell people, even other Indians, that I was Telugu and they would have no idea what that meant: Hari Kondabolu|last=Chitnis|first=Deepak|date=2014-03-04|website=The American Bazaar|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-05}} Kondabolu attended public schools in [[Queens]]: PS 69 in [[Jackson Heights, Queens|Jackson Heights]], PS 115 in [[Floral Park, New York|Floral Park]], MS 172 in Floral Park,{{Cite web|url=http://www.uft.org/noteworthy-grads/noteworthy-graduates-hari-kondabolu-comedian|title=Noteworthy graduates: Hari Kondabolu, comedian|last=Kondabolu|first=Hari|date=2015-10-01|website=United Federation of Teachers|series=New York Teacher|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-08}}{{Cite web|url=http://schools.nyc.gov/SchoolPortals/26/Q172/default.htm|title=WELCOME - Irwin Altman Middle School 172 - Q172 - New York City Department of Education|website=schools.nyc.gov|access-date=2016-08-08}} and [[Townsend Harris High School]] in [[Flushing, New York|Flushing,]] where he graduated in 2000. While a high school student, Kondabolu repeatedly watched a [[Margaret Cho]] special on the then-new [[Comedy Central]] cable network "in awe, because up until then I had never seen an Asian-American comedian. There she was up there—strong and funny and talking about her parents. That was the first time I thought maybe I could try this." He began writing and performing in comic skits in his global studies class at Townsend Harris, and produced and performed in a comedy night during his senior year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/16/493616808/hari-kondabolu-says-his-mom-is-hilarious-and-not-because-of-her-accent|title=Hari Kondabolu Says His Mom Is Hilarious — And Not Because Of Her Accent|last=Kondabolu|first=Hari|date=|website=NPR.org|access-date=2017-05-15|quote="I had a teacher - my favorite teacher, Chris Hackney, he used to have little breaks in class where I was able to do stand-up....He was global studies....We would have these press conferences where people would present articles and things that happened that week. And then each group would have to do little commercials and skits. And after a while, it was, like, kind of obvious that I was the one who was going to be doing them every single week. That was a huge confidence boost and feel that rush, you know, was incredibly."}} == Education and early activist career == Kondabolu continued performing standup when he attended [[Bowdoin College]]; he called his years at Bowdoin "incredibly formative"{{Cite web|url=http://community.bowdoin.edu/news/2015/07/leaving-the-late-show/|title=Leaving the ‘Late Show’|last=O'Donnell|first=Matt|date=2015-07-06|website=community.bowdoin.edu|publisher=Bowdoin News|access-date=2016-08-07}} and continues to spend part of every year in Maine.[http://www.sfstandup.com/blog/2008/10/15/interview-with-hari-kondabolu/ Hari Kondabolu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320111801/http://www.sfstandup.com/blog/2008/10/15/interview-with-hari-kondabolu/ |date=2012-03-20 }}. SFstandup.com, 15 October 2008. By Nato Green. Retrieved 27 Dec. 2011. He studied at [[Wesleyan University]] during his third year, focusing on identity and race, globalization, and "the impact of popular culture on society".{{Cite news|url=|title=Interning with Senators|last=|first=|date=2003-07-25|work=News India - Times|page=21|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} ''[[The Bowdoin Orient]]'' reported: "While spending his junior year at Wesleyan University developed Kondabolu as a 'scholar and an artist' because of the campus's politics and a thriving art scene, Bowdoin provided Kondabolu with the audience to hear that art. Kondabolu left for Wesleyan as a sophomore, but word of mouth made his audience even larger when he returned to Bowdoin as a senior."[http://orient.bowdoin.edu/orient/article.php?date=2007-02-23§ion=4&id=2 Hari Kondabolu '04 - Live]. The Bowdoin Orient. By Kelsey Abbruzzese. 23 Feb. 2007. Retrieved 27 Dec. 2011. Kondabolu served as the music director for campus radio station [[WBOR]].{{Cite news|url=http://studorgs.bowdoin.edu/wbor/zine/december04.pdf |title=The Top Hari Kondabolu Songs of 2004 |last=Kondabolu |first=Hari |date=December 2004 |work=WBOR Presents: Flip Your Shit |pages=2–4 |archive-date=2005-04-28 |access-date=2016-08-11 |via= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050428180119/http://studorgs.bowdoin.edu/wbor/zine/december04.pdf |df= }} In the summer of 2002, motivated by seeing the rise in [[Hate crime|hate crimes]] in the US after [[September 11 attacks|9/11]],{{Cite news|url=|title=Brave New World|last=Pais|first=Arthur J.|date=2007-05-04|work=|newspaper=India Abroad|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} Kondabolu interned with the Queens district attorney's office in its Hate Crimes/Anti-Bias/Youth Gangs Bureau, an experience that motivated him to pursue a career in which he would "improve the lives of minorities." In 2003, he was accepted into the Indian American Center for Political Awareness's Washington Leadership Program, which placed him in an internship with the Washington, DC office of Senator [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary Rodham Clinton]].{{Cite news|url=|title=Washington Leadership Program placed 15 interns for the summer; Alkesh Amin, Hari Kondabolu, Sushil Jacob interned with and had opportunity to interact with eminent Senators|last=Dumm|first=Christopher|date=2003-07-25|work=News India - Times|page=21|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} Immediately following the internship in Clinton's office, Kondabolu wrote:
this summer was the most fulfilling experience of my life.... Indian-American politicians like [[Swati Dandekar]] (Democrat Iowa State Representative) and (Maryland House Majority Leader) [[Kumar P. Barve|Kumar Barve]] (Democrat) were inspirations to me, as they proved that skin color would not hold me back if I did not let it.{{Cite news|url=|title='WLP helped me see ways I could make a difference'|last=Kondabolu|first=Hari|date=2003-11-07|work=|newspaper=News India - Times|page=22|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}}
Kondabolu also served internships with South Asian American Leaders of Tomorrow and [[South Asian Youth Action]]. After graduating from Bowdoin with a B.A. in Government and a minor in Asian Studies in 2004,{{Cite news|url=http://www.bowdoin.edu/commencement/archives/pdf/commencement04.pdf|title=Bowdoin College Commencement program|last=|first=|date=2004-05-29|work=|publisher=Bowdoin College|department=Candidates for the A.B. degree, May 2004|page=10|quote=Hari Karthikeya Kondabolu: Government; Minor: Asian Studies .... Holliswood, New York|access-date=2016-08-05|via=}} Kondabolu had no intention of pursuing a stand-up comedy career.{{Cite web|url=http://logger.believermag.com/post/91059744384/hari-kondabolu-and-alex-edelman-in-conversation|title=Hari Kondabolu and Alex Edelman in Conversation|last=|first=|date=2014-07-07|website=The Believer Logger|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810150248/http://logger.believermag.com/post/91059744384/hari-kondabolu-and-alex-edelman-in-conversation|archivedate=2016-08-10|df=}} He moved to [[Seattle]] and took the [[Law School Admission Test|LSAT]] preparatory to applying to law school, and worked as an immigrant rights organizer in Seattle for the organization Hate Free Zone (later renamed as OneAmerica) from 2005 to 2007.{{Cite web|url=http://www.seattlemet.com/articles/2014/6/2/pramila-jayapal-sees-the-big-picture-june-2014|title=Pramila Jayapal Sees the Big Picture {{!}} News & City Life {{!}} Seattle Met|website=www.seattlemet.com|access-date=2016-07-25}} As part of Hate Free Zone's "Liberty and Justice for All", he led a monthly conversation project focusing on immigration and human rights,{{Cite news|url=|title=Conversations can lead to positive action|last=Nguyen|first=Nhien|date=2006-08-20|work=|newspaper=International Examiner|page=3|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} saying, "Grassroots organizers know; intimate meetings and real dialogue can cut through the cacophony like nothing else."{{Cite news|url=|title=April 5 is "Night of 1,000 Conversations" about immigration and human rights|last=Kondabolu|first=Hari|date=2007-03-21|work=|newspaper=International Examiner|page=3|access-date=2016-08-06|via=Proquest}} He found his organizing work fulfilling:
I loved organizing, and, you know, I was working with victims of hate crimes, I was doing some work in detention centers and meeting families whose - you know, who had family members who were going to be deported, and, you know, it was really powerful, workplace discrimination cases...{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=305509473|title=For Comic Hari Kondabolu, Explaining The Joke IS The Joke|last=Gross|first=Terry|date=2014-04-21|website=National Public Radio|series=Fresh Air|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}}
Although his stand-up comedy career was gaining traction in 2007, he was accepted to the Masters in Human Rights program at the [[London School of Economics]] in 2007, and thus took a hiatus year from stand-up to earn his MSc.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1 August 2007 – 31 July 2008|title=Degrees Awarded in Autumn 2008|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/aboutLSE/keyFacts/LSEDigest/pdf/LSEDigest2007-08.pdf|department=|journal=LSE Digest|chapter=|edition=|publisher=The London School of Economics and Political Science|volume=|issue=|page=76|doi=|pmid=|access-date=2016-08-05|quote=MSc in Human Rights: ... Merit ... Hari Karthikeya Kondabolu|via=}}{{cite web|title=Comedian Hari Kondabolu On Diversity, Race And Burger King|first=Elizabeth|last=Blair|work=[[NPR]]|date=July 18, 2013|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/codeswitch/2013/07/18/203034882/comedian-hari-kondabolu-on-diversity-race-and-burger-king}} ==Stand-up comedy== While in Seattle, Kondabolu began participating in its alternative comedy scene.{{Cite web|url=http://www.harikondabolu.com/bio/|title=Bio — Hari Kondabolu|website=www.harikondabolu.com|access-date=2016-04-22}} His act included "a bit where I used to read the U.S. citizenship application onstage". In 2006, Kondabolu performed at the [[Bumbershoot]] Music and Arts Festival in Seattle, which he credits as his "big break", as a booker for [[The Comedy Festival|HBO's Comedy Festival]] saw his name on the Bumbershoot website. Kondabolu also filmed "Hari Kondabolu: Warn Your Relatives" in Seattle and released the special on Netflix in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/05/in-warn-your-relatives-hari-kondabolu-steps-into-t.html|title=In Warn Your Relatives, Hari Kondabolu Steps into the Spotlight and Nails It|work=pastemagazine.com|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://tv.avclub.com/hari-kondabolu-gives-you-more-to-think-about-in-warn-yo-1825826194|title=Hari Kondabolu gives you more to think about in Warn Your Relatives|last=Adams|first=Erik|work=TV Club|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.avclub.com/warn-your-relatives-hari-kondabolus-new-special-is-bes-1825830196|title=Warn Your Relatives: Hari Kondabolu's new special is best when it's at its simplest|last=Upadhyaya|first=Kayla Kumari|work=The A.V. Club|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en-US}} [[File:Hari-kondabolu-onstage 3.jpg|thumb|left|Kondabolu on stage in 2017]] Kondabolu has since made several television appearances as a stand-up comic. He made his first notable television appearance on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' in 2007, when he also began to appear in a variety of national comedy festivals, including the 2007 [[The Comedy Festival|HBO US Comedy Arts Festival]].Scanlon, T. "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to a Human Rights Master's Degree", Seattle Times, July 24, 2007 In October 2012, he performed stand-up on an episode of ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' and, in March 2014, he performed stand-up on ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]''. He has made several appearances on [[Comedy Central]], including a 2008 episode of ''[[Live at Gotham]]'',{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/live-at-gotham/episode-6-season-3/live-at-gotham/279792/|title=Live at Gotham|website=TVGuide.com|access-date=2016-09-02}} three episodes of ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show]]'' in 2010 and 2012,{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/episode-2-season-1/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/299769/|title=John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show: Season 1, Episode 2|last=|first=|date=|website=TVGuide.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-02}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/episode-1-season-3/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/299769/|title=John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show: Season 3, Episode 1|last=|first=|date=|website=TVGuide.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-02}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/episode-5-season-3/john-olivers-new-york-stand-up-show/299769/|title=John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show: Season 3, Episode 5|last=|first=|date=|website=TVGuide.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-02}} and most prominently, his own episode of ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'' which aired on February 11, 2011.{{Citation|title=Hari Kondabolu|date=2011-02-11|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1839804/|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=2016-08-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.sys-con.com/node/1651056|title='COMEDY CENTRAL Presents' is Back! Featuring Today's Best and Brightest Stand-Up Talent, the 15th Season Premieres Friday, January 21 at 11:00 p.m.|last=|first=|date=2010-12-15|website=news.sys-con.com|publisher=PR Newswire|access-date=2016-08-05|quote=Fresh new episodes from this season will include stand-up performances from Jack Whitehall, Al Jackson, Chelsea Peretti, Chris D'Elia, Hari Kondabolu, Jay Larson, Jessi Klein, Kyle Kinane, Louis Katz, Matt Fulchiron, Mike Vecchione, Natasha Leggero, Nate Bargatze and Sheng Wang.}} He has also appeared a number of times on British television, including on ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'' in 2011 and ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'' in 2012. In 2012, he had a recurring sketch as part of [[BBC Three]]'s ''[[Live at the Electric]]'' hosted by [[Russell Kane]].{{cite web|title=Hari Kondabolu|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00s06xy/contributors/hari-kondabolu|work=[[BBC]]}} He has also performed at the [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]]{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2011/10/das-racist-cover-story-these-colors-dont-run/|title=Das Racist Cover Story: These Colors Don't Run|author=Hari Kondabolu|publisher=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=October 17, 2011|accessdate=2011-10-17}} and was a featured comedian for the [[US State Department]]-sponsored "Make Chai Not War" comedy showcase in [[India]] in 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/01/04/144688443/state-department-sends-chai-comedy-tour-to-india|title=State Department Sends 'Chai' Comedy Tour To India|website=NPR.org|access-date=2016-08-05}}{{Cite web|url=https://photos.state.gov/libraries/kolcata/231771/PDFs/Bulletin_January%202012.pdf|title=American Center Kolkata Bulletin|last=|first=|date=January 2012|website=The US State Department|publisher=The American Center, Kolkata, India|access-date=2016-08-05}} From 2012 to 2013, he was on the writing staff for the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] comedy series ''[[Totally Biased with W. Kamau Bell]]'', produced by [[Chris Rock]] and hosted by [[W. Kamau Bell]], on which he often appeared as a correspondent. During that period, [[Rand Paul]] criticized the "Make Chai Not War" initiative during Congressional hearings on [[2012 Benghazi attack|the Benghazi controversy]]. Kondabolu responded in a Totally Biased segment, observing that the approximately $800 million USD that the State Department spends yearly sending artists to perform worldwide is far less than the US spends on war: "apparently after you spend trillions starting wars, people get angry at you."{{Citation|last=Hari Kondabolu|title=Benghazi Senate Hearing by Hari Kondabolu|date=2015-12-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DGKuQOeLEsg|work=Totally Biased with W. Kamau Bell|accessdate=2016-08-07}} His first stand-up comedy album, ''[[Waiting for 2042]]'', was released in March 2014 on [[Kill Rock Stars]].{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Comedy Listings for March 14–20|date=March 13, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/14/arts/comedy-listings-for-march-14-20.html?_r=0}} His second comedy album, ''Mainstream American Comic'', was released on July 22, 2016 on [[Kill Rock Stars]].{{Cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2016/06/hari-kondabolus-new-album-mainstream-american-comic-is-out-next-month/|title=Hari Kondabolu’s New Album ‘Mainstream American Comic’ Is Out Next Month|date=2016-06-06|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/exclusive-hari-kondabolu-announces-new-record-prem-237698|title=Exclusive: Hari Kondabolu announces new record, premieres first track|author= Marah Eakin|date=June 6, 2016|publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=2016-06-17}} It debuted at #1 on the [[ITunes Store|iTunes US]] comedy charts{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/harikondabolu/status/756928273314148352?lang=en|title=Hari Kondabolu on Twitter|access-date=2016-07-24}} and at #2 on the Billboard comedy charts.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/comedy-albums|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822192809/http://www.billboard.com/charts/comedy-albums|archivedate=2016-08-22|accessdate=2016-08-22|title=Comedy Albums: Top Stand-up Comedy Chart|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=August 22, 2016}} ===Artistic philosophy, focus, and development === Kondabolu's humor often centers on social issues such as poverty, racism, and a rejection of [[Indian stereotype|Indian stereotypes seen in media]]. He describes writing a July 2003 joke, which focused on the [[British Raj]] taking the [[Koh-i-Noor]] diamond from India, as "the first time I thought, 'Okay, this is who I actually am. This is what I actually believe.'"{{Cite web|url=https://www.saada.org/tides/article/20130311-1319|title=An Interview with Hari Kondabolu|last=Desai|first=Manan|date=2013-03-12|website=Tides Magazine|publisher=South Asian American Digital Archive|access-date=2016-08-07}} He takes issue with the label "political" being applied to his work, instead framing his comedy as addressing everyday issues that affect his and the audience's lives.{{Cite web|url=http://www.portlandmercury.com/portland/these-laughs-kill-fascists/Content?oid=2610407|title=These Laughs Kill Fascists: The "Political" Comedy of Laughter Against the Machine|last=Tonry|first=Andrew R|date=2010-06-17|website=Portland Mercury|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}} Kondabolu said: ''"''I called the record '''Mainstream American Comic''' because I believe the ideas I'm talking about should be part of the mainstream discussion.''"''{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/media/hari-kondabolu-americas-smartest-and-funniest-mainstream-comic|title=Hari Kondabolu: America's Smartest and Funniest 'Mainstream Comic'|last=Holloway|first=Kali|date=2016-07-21|newspaper=AlterNet|access-date=2016-08-07}} He compares his work to that of [[The Clash]], contrasting his approach to that of the [[Sex Pistols]]: instead of engaging in contrariness for contrariness's sake, he focuses on issues of justice and fairness.{{Cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/arts/361711/comedian-hari-kondabolu-gets-philosophical|title=Comedian Hari Kondabolu gets philosophical|last=MacPherson|first=Guy|date=2014-12-02|website=The Georgia Straight|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}} Early in Kondabolu's stand-up comedy career, he was willing to use [[Stereotype|stereotypes]] of Indians, including Indian accents, to get laughs. He characterizes his immediately post-[[September 11 attacks|9/11]] work as self-important political argument at the expense of humor; he credits his time in the Seattle stand-up scene with teaching him that "you need the joke. I learned to value the joke again."{{Cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2014/03/catching-up-with-hari-kondabolu.html|title=Catching Up With Hari Kondabolu|last=Ham|first=Robert|date=2014-03-10|website=Paste Magazine|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}} As of late 2017, Kondabolu is taking his mother's advice and diversifying the topics he discusses in his comedy, working on new material that puts more of his personal vulnerability onstage.{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/theater/you-cannot-kill-comedy-an-interview-with-comic-social-critic-and-twitter-troll-magnet-hari-kondabolu/|title=You cannot ‘kill comedy’: an interview with comic, social critic and Twitter-troll magnet Hari Kondabolu|date=2017-12-13|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en-US}} === Podcast host === He and his younger brother Ashok performed in a monthly mostly improvised talk show together in [[New York City]] called ''Untitled Kondabolu Brothers Project''. Past guests have included [[Ajay Naidu]], [[Aasif Mandvi]], Bell, [[Leo Allen]], [[Victor Vazquez (musician)|Victor Vazquez]] (Kool AD of Das Racist), [[Charles Mudede]] and [[Blue Scholars]]. In January 2013, they started ''Untitled Kondabolu Brothers Podcast''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kondabolubrothers.com/|title=Kondabolu Brothers|website=www.kondabolubrothers.com|access-date=2016-04-22}} After a hiatus from 2015 onwards, the podcast debuted again as the ''Kondabolu Brothers Podcast'' in 2018 on the [[Earwolf]] label.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/harikondabolu/status/970437184074407936|title=The Kondabolu Brothers Podcast debuts THIS THURSDAY MARCH 8TH on @earwolf.|last=Kondabolu|first=Hari|date=4 Mar 2018|website=@harikondabolu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-15}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.earwolf.com/show/kondabolu-brothers/|title=Kondabolu Brothers podcast on Earwolf|website=www.earwolf.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-15}} He is a co-host of the podcast ''[[Politically Re-Active]]'' with Bell, which debuted in June 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stitcher.com/podcast/panoply/politically-reactive-with-w-kamau-bell-hari-kondabolu|title=Politically Re-Active with W. Kamau Bell & Hari Kondabolu|website=www.stitcher.com|access-date=2016-06-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808014704/http://www.stitcher.com/podcast/panoply/politically-reactive-with-w-kamau-bell-hari-kondabolu|archivedate=2016-08-08|df=}} He also debuted as a rotating host on ''[[The Bugle]]'' alongside [[Andy Zaltzman]] in the fall of 2016 after the departure of [[John Oliver (comedian)|John Oliver]].{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/harikondabolu/status/739783721121898497|title=Hari Kondabolu on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-21}}{{Cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/the-bugle/vib-very-important-bugle|title=VIB - Very Important Bugle|website=Soundcloud|publisher=[[The Bugle]] podcast|access-date=2016-06-21}} == Online activism == In 2014, Kondabolu started an online campaign joining [[Washington Redskins name controversy|activists]] asking the [[Washington Redskins]] to change their name or logo,{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/yourcommunity/2014/10/comedian-urges-washington-redskins-to-adopt-sunburned-white-person-as-their-logo.html|title=Comedian urges Washington Redskins to adopt 'sunburned white person' as their logo|last=O'Neil|first=Lauren|date=2014-10-21|website=CBC|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}} suggesting viewers use the [[Twitter]] [[hashtag]] #NewRedskinsLogo to share their proposed changes.{{Cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/101974/this-comedian-has-a-brilliant-alternative-to-the-redskins-logo|title=This Comedian Has a Brilliant Alternative to the Redskins Logo|last=Valinsky|first=Jordan|date=2014-10-21|website=Mic|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-08}} Kondabolu argued that if Redskins owners and fans were unwilling to change their name away from one "stereotyping Native Americans", then the Redskins logo should change to one portraying "a severely sunburned white person".{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/sapna/hari-kondabolu-redskins-logo-campaign|title=A Comedian Is Campaigning To Make The Redskins Logo A Sunburned White Guy|last=Maheshwari|first=Sapna|date=2014-10-21|website=Buzzfeed|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-08}} In 2015, Kondabolu, criticizing Louisiana governor [[Bobby Jindal]] as "disingenuous", started the #BobbyJindalIsSoWhite Twitter hashtag.{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2015/0625/Bobby-Jindal-wants-to-downplay-his-Indian-heritage-but-Twitter-won-t-let-him-video|title=Bobby Jindal wants to downplay his Indian heritage, but Twitter won't let him (+video)|last=Caspari|first=Sarah|date=2015-06-25|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|issn=0882-7729|access-date=2016-08-07}} He said: "You can say that about all politicians, but there's something about how he uses his story about being the son of Indian immigrants and then at the same time talks about how we're all Americans and should get rid of hyphenated identities [that bothers me]."{{Cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/121382/bobby-jindal-hari-kondabolu-twitter-so-white|title=This Indian-American Comedian Turned Bobby Jindal Into the Internet's Biggest Punchline|last=King|first=Jamilah|date=2015-06-29|website=Mic|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}} Each day during the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|presidency]] of [[Donald Trump]], Kondabolu [[Twitter|tweets]]: "REMINDER FOR DAY [number] OF PRESIDENCY: THIS IS NOT NORMAL (AND NORMAL WASN’T THAT GREAT EITHER)."{{Cite news|url=http://mspmag.com/arts-and-culture/the-morning-after/laughter-makes-the-truth-come-easier/|title=Making America Laugh Again|last=Matt|first=Lianna|date=2017-04-14|work=Mpls.St.Paul Magazine|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en-us}} == Acting and film == Kondabolu wrote and starred in Zia Mohajerjasbi's 2007 short film ''Manoj'',{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/1807851|title=MANOJ|last=Mohajerjasbi|first=Zia|date=2008-09-24|website=Vimeo|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-11}} which has played in comedy and film festivals around the world, including the [[Just for Laughs]] Festivals in [[Montreal]] and [[Chicago]], and which mocks comedians who broadly exploit their ethnic backgrounds for their material.{{Cite web|url=http://www.harikondabolu.com/2010/05/manoj-krishnamurthy-is-dead/|title=MANOJ KRISHNAMURTHY IS DEAD — Hari Kondabolu|website=www.harikondabolu.com|access-date=2016-04-22}} In ''Manoj ,'' Kondabolu portrays both Manoj, a fictional Indian immigrant comic who plays to white audiences by repeating their stereotypes of South Asians, and an Indian-American who is critical of Manoj's approach. He made ''Manoj'' to speak to and about artists of color; as Shruti Swamy summarized, "for Kondabolu, the film is about [[Minstrel show|minstrelsy]]-the idea of making a caricature of your background, or playing into stereotypes, not to challenge them, but to reinforce them".{{Cite news|url=|title=Yes, We Can|last=Swamy|first=Shruti|date=February 2009|work=|newspaper=India Currents|issue=22.10|pages=10–12, 14|access-date=|via=ProQuest}} Kondabolu portrayed "Crossword Businessman" in the 2009 film ''[[All About Steve]]'',{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0881891/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm|title=All About Steve - Full Cast & Crew|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-05}} a movie he mocks in ''Mainstream American Comic''.{{cite AV media |date=2016-07-22 |title=Mainstream American Comic |medium=Comedy album |language=English |url=https://harikondabolu.bandcamp.com/album/mainstream-american-comic |section=A Special Blend of South Asian Humor |publisher=Kill Rock Stars}} He also played a supporting role in the 2016 film ''[[Five Nights in Maine]]'',{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/2026273/Five-Nights-in-Maine/full-credits.html|title=Five Nights in Maine (2016)|website=Turner Classic Movies|access-date=2016-08-05}} although none of his scenes were included in the final 75-minute cut of the film.{{Cite web|url=http://www.infiniteguest.org/secret-skin/2015/09/hari-kondabolu-pro-wrestling/|title=Episode #31: Hari Kondabolu|last=Kruse|first=Andy|access-date=2016-08-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/five-nights-maine-looks-grief-close--240400|title=Five Nights In Maine looks at grief close up|date=2016-08-02|access-date=2016-08-06}} Also in 2016, he appeared as a fictionalized version of himself in the [[Comedy Central]] [[web series]] ''White Flight''.{{Cite web|url=http://thelaughbutton.com/television/matt-braunger-launches-new-webseries-white-flight-and-tour-dates/|title=Matt Braunger launches new webseries "White Flight" and tour dates - The Laugh Button|website=The Laugh Button|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-22}} Kondabolu is the star, creator, and executive director of ''[[The Problem with Apu]]'', a documentary about [[Apu Nahasapeemapetilon|Apu]] from ''[[The Simpsons]]'' that premiered in November 2017 on [[TruTV]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/shows/the-problem-with-apu/blog/complete-credits/complete-credits.html|title=The Problem with Apu - Credits - truTV.com|last=|first=|date=|website=truTV|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026145933/http://www.trutv.com/shows/the-problem-with-apu/blog/complete-credits/complete-credits.html|archive-date=2017-10-26|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.docnyc.net/film/the-problem-with-apu/|title=The Problem With Apu|last=|first=|date=|work=DOC NYC|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US}} The film contextualizes Apu within web|url=http://mainetoday.com/do-this-2/comedian-hari-kondabolu-bowdoin-college-grad-known-routines-race-politics-social-justice-will-play-port-city-music-hall-portland-friday/|title=Comedian Hari 2016|publisher=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|author=Lisa de Moraes|accessdate=2016-05-15}} == Critical reception and honors == The ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' called Kondabolu in mid-2016 "one of the most necessary political comedians working today", saying that "his material addresses culture and current events through a sharp lens of progressive politics and his clever, very funny perspective".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/29/arts/comedy-listings-for-july-29-aug-4.html|title=Comedy Listings for July 29-Aug. 4|date=2016-07-28|newspaper=The New York Kondabolu|last=Tonry|first=Andrew R.|date=2011-11-09|website=Blogtown|publisher=The Portland Mercury|access-date=2016-08-07}} [[New York University]]'s Asian/Pacific/American Institute chose Kondabolu as its [[Artist-in-residence|Artist in Residence]] for the 2014-2015 academic year, the first time that a comedian had been selected for that honor.{{Citation|last=apainstitute|title=Kickoff Event for Hari Kondabolu, the 2014-15 A/P/A Institute at NYU Artist-in-Residence|date=2014-12-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vngPdeR7SxM|accessdate=2016-08-07}}{{Cite
